page.title: 01Parish Of Friston, Suffolk
page.content: The landscape is rural including cultivated farmland, common, woodland, farms in Snape parish, part of Knodshall Village (including the local primary school) and all Friston village. Blackheath estate owns much farmland, some of which is tenanted. In Friston Village there are: The Chequers P.H.; a post windmill built 1811/12 under restoration and reputedly the tallest of its kind; St. Mary's Church, 11th/12thC., showing a recently uncovered north door outline; a stricy Baptist Chapel built hexagonally in 1831; a post office (no shop); a shelter/seat commemorating King George V Jubilee; a hand carved wooden village sign commemorating Queen Eliabeth 11 Silver Jubilee. A number of long standing village families still live in Friston but houses are often bought up by people
